ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
knowledge: influence of pharma across time and space, history of certain classes of products
skills: writing different kinds of assignments (analysis, policy proposal, longform "biography")
insights: pharmaceuticals shape and reflect the way we live
about pharmaceuticals and the way they have played a role in american healthcare
Critical thinking and engaging with the history of medicine
Learned a LOT about pharmaceutical regulation.
Writing, persuasive argumentative writing, critical thinking

Learned a lot about how to analyze a federal agency and all the intricacies involved in decision and policy making. Also learned a lot about the pharmaceutical industry and how to contextualize actions that seem immoral (and often are) within a broader system to target the underlying issue and think of the base consequences and solutions.

We explored the history of the pharmaceutical industry and looked specifically at certain classes of drugs (antibiotics, contraception, etc.). This class taught me how to read and analyze historical documents.

This class had me learn a lot about the FDA, and it turned some of the more boring bureaucratic or organizational histories into an interesting discussion. Readings were good, and I learned a lot from them.
An overview of pharmaceuticals and their regulation

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: manageable and fascinating readings, great integration of readings into class discussion, appropriate balance between professor lecturing and students discussing, really unique and well-designed assignments
weaknesses: honestly none
areas of improvement: " "

strength - lessened reading load meant I could engage more thoroughly 
weakness - class felt sort of dominated by a few voices, but it  was nice to learn from them!
I thought the readings were very dense and not super interesting at times.
Professor Schwartz incredibly passionate, knowledgeable and compassionate

The content is really interesting and the assignments complement the course really well. I think the course would be improved if Professor Schwartz lecture a little bit more; he's an expert in the field and it would have been great to learn more directly from him.

I appreciated how much conversation we were able to have with one another in class, despite the fact that the seminar was over Zoom. I also felt like the assignments were well thought out and pushed me to think about the pharmaceutical industry from different perspectives, whether that be from a companys history or through advertising.
Strengths: The course is good in that students learn a lot about the FDA and its history, as well as specific types of pharmaceuticals. Professor Schwartz was very encouraging the whole time.
Couldn't be better! Jason is fantastic.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: all succeeded
Seminar style
I think we did a good job of small group discussion online.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 110% - the optimally-designed Yale seminar
Yes! Professor  is  amazing, you will learn so much, in a generally not stressful setting.

I would 100% recommend this course to another student. Not only is the professor very understanding and willing to work with you, but the topics covered are always so interesting. I think a person of any major would find this class an exciting one.
Yes, Professor Schwartz is very engaging and helpful
Yes, Professor Schwartz is an AMAZING teacher and I think the class would be amazing in person. The 2 hour Zoom seminars were pretty exhausting, but I think in person it would be a great class.
Yes! Anything Jason teaches, I recommend. Hes stellar and thoughtful and cares a bunch.
Absolutely
Yes! The content was really interesting, the assignments had value, and Professor Schwartz is a great person to learn from.

Yes! This is a great HSHM course that allows you to pull from contemporary knowledge to contextualize history. I enjoyed the conversations and questions my classmates would ask and the (virtual) classroom environment was positive. Professor Schwartz was also great at leading and guiding the discussions, and I highly recommend you take a course with him.
Yes! It was really interesting, and Professor Schwartz is very kind.
Take a course with Jason if at all possible!!
